name: ScholarAssist
description: ScholarAssist is an AI‑powered Academic Research Assistant that autonomously searches scholarly databases (PubMed, arXiv), extracts key findings, formats citations, and drafts literature‑review sections. Researchers can ask for a review on any topic and receive a polished, citation‑rich write‑up ready for inclusion in manuscripts or grant proposals.

tools.name: search_database
tools.description: Search a scholarly database (PubMed or arXiv) with a free‑text query and return up to `max_results` items. Each result includes title, authors, year, DOI/arXiv‑ID, and a short abstract snippet formatted in Markdown.

max_results.description: Maximum number of results to return.

tools.name: fetch_paper
tools.description: Retrieve the full metadata (title, authors, abstract, journal, year, DOI/arXiv‑ID, link) for a paper given its unique identifier.

id_type.description: Specifies whether the identifier is a DOI or an arXiv ID.

tools.name: extract_findings
tools.description: Analyse an abstract or a full‑text passage and return the core methods, results, and conclusions as concise bullet points.

text.description: The abstract or passage to analyse.

tools.name: format_citation
tools.description: Format a citation from supplied metadata into a chosen citation style (APA or MLA). Returns the citation as a plain string.

authors.description: List of author names in "First Last" order.

journal.description: Journal or conference name (optional for arXiv papers).

doi.description: Digital Object Identifier (optional for arXiv papers).

tools.name: summarize_section
tools.description: Create a narrative paragraph that synthesises a list of extracted findings into a coherent literature‑review segment of roughly `target_length` words.

target_length.description: Desired word count of the summary.

tools.name: draft_review_section
tools.description: Combine one or more summary paragraphs and their associated citations into a polished literature‑review section. Allows selection of tone (formal or neutral).

topic.description: The specific sub‑topic of the review (e.g., "intermittent fasting and insulin sensitivity").

citations.description: Formatted citation strings that correspond to the summaries.

examples.description: User asks for a short literature‑review on intermittent fasting and metabolic health. The assistant searches PubMed, retrieves two key papers, extracts findings, formats APA citations, summarises, and drafts a paragraph.

messages.content:
- Alternate‑day fasting for 12 weeks increased peripheral insulin sensitivity by ~15% in humans.
- Improvement confirmed via gold‑standard euglycemic clamp.
- No adverse effects on body weight reported.

- 8‑hour time‑restricted feeding for 8 weeks restored insulin sensitivity in diet‑induced obese mice.
- Fasting glucose levels returned to normal.
- Enhanced insulin signaling (IRS‑1/AKT pathway) observed.
Formatting APA citations for the two papers.

findings:

- Improvement confirmed via gold‑standard euglycemic clamp.

- 8‑hour time‑restricted feeding for 8 weeks restored insulin sensitivity in diet‑induced obese mice.

messages.content: Recent controlled studies demonstrate that intermittent fasting markedly improves insulin sensitivity across species. In a 12‑week human trial, alternate‑day fasting raised peripheral insulin sensitivity by approximately 15% without weight loss, as measured by euglycemic clamp (Harvey et al., 2022). Parallel work in obese mice showed that an 8‑hour time‑restricted feeding window for eight weeks normalized fasting glucose and reactivated key insulin‑signaling pathways (Cheng & Zhang, 2021). Together, these findings suggest that restricting the daily eating window can serve as a potent, non‑pharmacological strategy to enhance metabolic health.

arguments.text: We propose a new adaptive encoding scheme for variational quantum classifiers that reduces circuit depth while preserving expressivity. Experiments on synthetic and MNIST‑encoded data show a 30% reduction in gate count with comparable accuracy.

A quantum neural network architecture that naturally handles graph‑structured inputs by encoding adjacency information into multi‑qubit entanglement patterns. Demonstrated on citation‑network classification tasks, achieving state‑of‑the‑art performance with fewer parameters than classical GNNs.

We evaluate several quantum kernel approaches on benchmark datasets from chemistry (QM9) and finance (stock‑price prediction). Results highlight regimes where quantum kernels outperform classical RBF kernels, especially with limited training samples.
A hybrid algorithm that combines quantum policy networks with classical value estimation. Tested on OpenAI Gym environments, the method converges faster than purely classical deep RL baselines.

Introducing a noise‑robust gradient descent method for training quantum models on NISQ devices by integrating zero‑noise extrapolation and Pauli‑twirling. Experiments on a 27‑qubit IBM device show up to 2× improvement in training fidelity.

messages.content: Introduces adaptive data encoding for variational quantum classifiers, cutting circuit depth by ~30% while keeping accuracy comparable.
Presents a quantum neural network that directly encodes graph structures, achieving state‑of‑the‑art graph‑classification with fewer parameters.
Benchmarks quantum kernel methods on chemistry and finance datasets, showing advantage over classical kernels when training data is scarce.
Combines quantum policy networks with classical value functions, yielding faster convergence in standard RL benchmarks.
Applies error‑mitigation (zero‑noise extrapolation + Pauli‑twirling) to quantum gradient descent, doubling training fidelity on a 27‑qubit device.
